thread.title: Alexandra golfer Kili Tabakau will play with pros in NZ Open
thread.title_full: Alexandra golfer Kili Tabakau will play with pros in NZ Open

author: Rhys Chamberlain
title: Alexandra golfer Kili Tabakau will play with pros in NZ Open
text:
Alexandra golfer Kili Tabakau will play with pros in NZ Open RHYS CHAMBERLAIN Last updated 14:39, February 27 2017 Supplied 
NZ Open playoff hole winner Kili Tabakau, left of the Alexandra Golf Club, with Millbrook's Brian Spicer. 
An Alexandra golfer has won the right to play the New Zealand Open after winning a playoff hole in a locals' challenge. 
Kili Tabakau put his ball closet to the pin on Millbrook Resort's 18th hole to secure a spot in one of New Zealand's premiere golf events. 
The former Aucklander, who moved to Central Otago in November, said he was "pretty lucky and pretty excited" about the opportunity to play in next week's tournament. 
"I just went up there and enjoyed it," Tabakau said. "I'm pretty excited to be honest." 
READ MORE: * Major winner YE Yang to play at New Zealand Open 
The 49-year-old was one of about 20 Alexandra players to compete in a local club qualifying tournament and his name was drawn to represent the club after he scored more than 34 stablesfords. 
Tabakau lined up with six other players from Arrowtown, Kelvin Heights, Cromwell, Wanaka, Lake Hawea and Clyde golf clubs at Millbrook on Saturday. 
He wasn't too nervous leading up to the competition. 
"I practiced a bit through the week thinking, 'if I don't get it, I don't get it'. 
"I just wanted to get out there and enjoy it." Ad Feedback 
Tabakau put the first of two balls off the back of the green but followed if up with a shot that landed about 2m from the pin. 
Being drawn first, he was nervous waiting to see if any of the other golfers got closer. They didn't. 
Tabakau, a golfer for 17 years who plays off an 11 handicap, won't know which pro he will play with until next Tuesday when the groups are drawn but was hoping to play with Ryan Fox and to play well. 
"I didn't think until later that I'd be playing in one of the top competitions. 
"At the end of the day I know I'm representing Alexandra. I want to get in and post a good score." 
NZ Open assistant to the tournament director and The Hills head coach Allan McKay said he was really happy for a "humble" Tabakau, 
"He'll have a wonderful week just being part of the event. What a thrill." 
McKay said each of the seven players all "hit it well" and enjoyed themselves in the playoff. 
Tabakau receives a minimum of two days play at Millbrook and The Hills with a professional player in the Open Challenge. 
A professional field of 144 players will play the first two rounds of the NZ Open alternately at Millbrook Resort and The Hills before the second round cut of 60 plays the final two rounds at Millbrook. 
The tournament also hosts 144 amateur players, each partnering with a professional.
